description.narrative: SDG Philanthropy Platform is a global and national facilitator connecting UN agencies, governments and private foundations helping optimize resources and efforts to achieve the SDGs by enabling effective collaboration with the broader ecosystem.

participating-org.narrative: UN Fund for International Partnerships (UNFIP) Turner Foundation

provider-org.narrative: UN Fund for International Partnerships (UNFIP) Turner Foundation
UN Fund for International Partnerships (UNFIP) Turner Foundation
UN Fund for International Partnerships (UNFIP) Turner Foundation

comment.narrative:
1. SDG Ecosystem Mapping for Ending Violence against Children in South Africa and Tanzania completed.
2. Philanthropy-government collaboration has been widely promoted in all pilot countries.
In Zambia, more than 70 participants, representing FBOs and religious groups as well as respective government ministries have been convened in a strategic meeting “Leveraging FBO’s outreach in delivering on Leaving No One Behind under the 7th National Development Plan and Sustainable Development Goals”, organized in Lusaka on 24th April 2018 in collaboration with the Ministry of National Guidance and Religious Affairs and the Ministry of National Development Planning. As a result, 10 strategic recommendations have been developed to further guide and enhance FBO-Government collaboration.
A roundtable discussion on Philanthropy and Government Investing in the SDGs was organized during the 2018 High Level Political Forum on the SDGs. The event took place on July 16, 2018 in New York, USA and was co-hosted by the Government of Ghana and African Union Permanent Observer to the United Nations. This interactive roundtable aimed to build greater momentum for creating a better policy and legal environment for philanthropy investing in the SDGs.
3. Philanthropy and Impact Investors Network Ghana (PIING) has been officially registered.
A new approach on supporting the local foundations in aligning of their strategies with the SDGs and a National Development Agenda has been tested in Colombia. In particular, the Platform facilitated the strategic consultations between the UN / UNDP Colombia Expert in education and Restrepo Barco Foundation, to help the latter develop their Theory of Change and M&E Framework, define short-term and long-term (impact) results, and inform the workplan for the next 2 years.
SDG Partnership Platform, a spin-off of the SDG Philanthropy Platform, has been launched in Kenya to support the Government of Kenya in delivering its “Big Four” Agenda.
4. Throughout 2018 SDG Philanthropy Platform has been represented at more than 20 global, regional and local events where the best experiences from the SDGPP activities in countries have been shared. Major highlights include roundtable discussions on Philanthropy and Government Investing in the SDGs at the 2018 HLPF and Innovative Financing for the SDGs at the margins of 2018 UNGA.
5. In Brazil, the Platform has been leading the work on the joint elaboration of 4 collaborative pathways towards accelerating progress on SDGs #4, #10, #16, and #17 by 30 major stakeholders. 5 dedicated workshops have been held and 4 scalable solutions have been jointly designed for implementation.
6. All 8 Innovation Challenge projects launched in 2017 have been successfully completed and are expected to deliver positive change in the lives of 27,000 direct beneficiaries in the short run and 8.5 million people over 5-year period. Subsequently, 9 joint monitoring visits (6 in Zambia and 3 in Ghana) have been undertaken to validate the progress made in the implementation of these initiatives. Furthermore, a dedicated wrap-up session was held with the Innovation Challenge winners to reflect on the successes, challenges, lessons learned and scaling opportunities.
7. 3 reports launched; 7 webinars organized; 39 articles, blogposts and newsletters produced.
8. SDGPP has 955 active users on its website; 7,441 followers on FB, 7,821 on Twitter, and 571 on Linkedin.

1. SDG Ecosystem and philanthropy mapping for China has been completed and visualized on the website.
2. On September 21, 2019, the SDG Partnership Platform in Kenya together with the Government of Kenya, UN in Kenya, the Rockefeller Foundation and UNDP Accelerator Lab Network co-hosted a high level-dialogue on Harnessing the Power of SDG Partnerships for the financing and delivery of Kenya’s development priorities. A Communique has been signed to inspire future action and support for Kenya’s Big Four Agenda and the launch of the co-created SDG Accelerator Lab has been announced. The latter initiative seeks to bring together the government, private sector, civil society, philanthropy, academia, and young people to re-imagine development for the 21st century.
SDGPP India has been instrumental in supporting the State Government of Jharkhand with the implementation of the Forest Right Act (FRA), which is a crucial means for the attainment of the SDGs related to gender equality, poverty reduction, income improvement and climate change mitigation, particularly with regard to tribal communities. FRA intervention in Jharkhand is being guided through an FRA cell, established in collaboration with the State Welfare Department, the nodal agency responsible for implementation of FRA. The Platform succeeded in expanding the initial UN-government partnership by reaching out to other actors and mobilizing necessary resources, skills and knowledge to provide comprehensive support for effective implementation of FRA and by addressing different bottlenecks to its implementation.
Ongoing activities include support to district officials with collecting and reporting data on submitted and rejected FRA claims, development of a Standard Operating Procedure (SoP) and designing and testing a Management Information System (MIS) for FRA implementation at different levels.
3. In Ghana, the Platform was actively engaged in the further development of the Philanthropy and Impact Investing Network of Ghana (PHIING). To date, 21 corporate foundations committed to become members of this network.
In Kenya, SDGPP maintained its engagement with philanthropic stakeholders through participation in the Conrad N. Hilton Foundation’s Annual Convening in April 2019 as well as support to the Kenya Philanthropy Forum and East Africa Philanthropy Network with developing a more detailed relationship structure. Additionally, important philanthropic players, such as the Conrad N. Hilton Foundation, the Rockefeller Foundation and the Ford Foundation have been brought onboard to the SDGPP expanded arm - the SDG Partnership Platform – a UNDAF (2018-2022) flagship programme in support of the Government of Kenyas Big Four agenda.
In Brazil, the SDG Philanthropy Platform has been leading the activities on improving the awareness on the SDG implementation and collaboration for 2030 Agenda among local foundations. A Steering Committee meeting was held on 2 April 2019 to validate the activities for 2019. Second Scaling Solutions workshop was co-hosted in partnership with the Rockefeller Philanthropy Advisors on 13 August 2019.
4. As a global and national facilitator that enables philanthropic organizations to optimize their resources and efforts for the achievement of the 2030 Agenda, the SDG Philanthropy Platform hosted, supported and participated in more than 20 events both at the global and national levels. Major highlights include: a) side event on the margins of the High-Level Political Forum 2019, titled Partnerships for Transformation: Philanthropy and the Sustainable Development Goals; b) side-event, named Unlocking the Full Potential of Philanthropy for Development, held during the 74th session of the UN General Assembly; c) strategic conversation on Boosting Domestic Philanthropy and Giving in and for the Global South, held during the 74th session of the UN General Assembly.
7. 2 Communications Campaigns designed and implemented; 23 blogposts, articles and newsletters developed; 2 guides on Philanthropy and the SDGs launched.
8. SDGPP website has been further updated, with 3 new webpages, namely SDGPP China, Our Success Stories and How to Engage, being launched and Our Work webpage being revised. SDGPP social media and online presence has been expanded to 2,200+ active users on its website; 7,394 followers on FB, 9,600 on Twitter and 900 on LinkedIn.
